name: methyl_propyl_sulfide
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: 1,3-propanedisulfide has a melting point of -109.4 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for comparison is propane, which has a melting point of -18.7 degrees Celsius. The introduction of a methyl group (–CH3) and a propyl group (–C(C)C) increases the molecular weight and size, which generally raises the melting point. However, the sulfur atom within the sulfide group creates additional hydrogen bonding potential, which can lower the melting point. The methyl group also introduces a bulky structure that can hinder crystalline structure formation, further lowering the melting point. The net effect should be a decreased melting point due to the combination of increased molecular weight and size and reduced crystalline structure formation.
